Sullivan: UK's burden seems light as a feather

The idea that UK is competing beneath a ponderous burden of expectations appears ludicrous

Sullivan: UK's burden seems light as a feather

12:03 a.m. EST November 26, 2014

Kentucky forward Willie Cauley-Stein, center, blocks the shot of Texas-Arlington guard Kaelon Wilson in the first half.(Photo: Jonathan Palmer/Special to The Courier-Journal)

2 CONNECT 6 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. – Forget the 100-pound coat. If John Calipari is going to make things interesting, he ought to outfit his Kentucky Wildcats with snowshoes, shackles, blindfolds and thumbscrews.

Maybe then, college basketball might regain some mystery. Maybe then, the nation's No. 1 team might start feeling some of the pressure Calipari claims it carries.

Because the idea that UK is competing beneath a ponderous burden of expectations is starting to look ludicrous. Hard on the heels of Sunday's 86-28 mauling of Montana State – the blowout that prompted Calipari's 100-pound coat metaphor -- the Wildcats thrashed Texas-Arlington Tuesday night, 92-44.

And it wasn't that close. Kentucky scored the last 28 points of the first half to take a 55-12 lead at intermission, blocking twice as many shots (eight) as the visiting Mavericks made from the field (four). If the second half was more respectable, it carried all of the suspense of a Road Runner cartoon.

If these 'Cats are feeling any pressure, it is primarily about maintaining their individual minutes on a team whose toughest competition appears in practice. If their movements are constricted by a 100-pound coat, they sure wear it well.

Video | UK's Booker on UT Arlington rout, hot shooting

Perhaps Kentucky is not a better team than the NBA's Philadelphia 76ers – despite former UK star Eric Bledsoe's boasts – but the 'Cats certainly appear capable of becoming Division I basketball's first undefeated champion since Bobby Knight's 1975-76 Indiana Hoosiers.

"I think it is very possible they could go undefeated," Texas-Arlington coach Scott Cross said. "I think if they play the way they did, together, as a team, where they go inside-outside and they're hitting shots, they're not going to lose, for sure. I think it would take a really poor shooting night and obviously somebody would have to have great size. It would have to be one of the powerhouse teams and they'd have to have an unbelievable night, I think, in order to knock 'em down.

"I mean, the way they're playing. . .I find it hard to believe that anybody could beat them right now."

RELATED: Kentucky cruises to 92-44 win over Texas-Arlington

RELATED: Game Rewind | UT Arlington UK's latest victim

RELATED: Instant Analysis | Kentucky-UT Arlington

The 'Cats will face more formidable tests than Texas-Arlington. There will be nights when an inspired opponent hits a high percentage of its three-point shots, limits Kentucky's possessions by forcing turnovers and achieves something akin to drama. It will be interesting to see well UK copes if one of its games is still close in the closing minutes.

Make no mistake: That's an "if," not a "when."

"Their size is absolutely unbelievable," Cross said. "We could have guys standing on chairs and we wouldn't be able to simulate it. They take up so much space and they close down gaps; it's pretty impressive. I thought we would be able to get a couple open looks. In the first half, we got zero open looks."

Video | Towns: Cats need to eat, defense a buffet

The tone was set before the first points were scored, when UT-Arlington guard Drew Charles tried to launch a mid-range jump shot and Kentucky's spry freshman Karl-Anthony Towns blocked it almost before it left Charles' hands.

Towns stands 6-foot-11, and his nimble presence on the perimeter can make a confident guard gun-shy. In 17 minutes of densely packed production, Towns scored 13 points, grabbed 11 rebounds, made four assists, and blocked three shots. Kentucky blocked 11 shots altogether Tuesday, and many of the UT-Arlington shots that were launched cleanly were forced from awkward angles and fell nowhere near the net.

There may be nights when Kentucky does not shoot sharply, but its size and athleticism should prevent defensive slumps. The quality of its depth means no player can afford to coast lest he lose playing time to another elite player.

"Everybody wants to talk about defense," Calipari said. "They all want to talk about the energy, the blocked shots and the length, and the story is you have 10 guys sharing minutes. That's the whole story in a nutshell.

"Why is this happening? Because they're allowing it to happen."

Unless their egos intrude, the Wildcats should be heavily favored to win it all and, perhaps, to win all of their games. They wear their 100-pound coat like a pocket square.

"Our biggest opponent," Karl-Anthony Towns said, "is ourselves."

Tim Sullivan can be reached at (502) 582-4650, by email at tsullivan@courier-journal.com, and on Twitter @TimSullivan714
